The Governor withdrew his emergency request for a court to stop enforcement of Atlanta’s requirement that faces masks be worn in all public places, while mediation over the state’s legal effort to block the mandate proceeds - July 28, 2020.
The governor is now mandating that everyone wear a face mask or covering while in essential businesses — or while waiting to get inside.
Governor Brad Little on Thursday announced Idaho will stay in Stage 4 for another two weeks. He took time to encourage Idahoans to wear masks, but said he “doubts” he will issue a statewide mandate.

Beginning on May 1, individuals will be required to wear a face-covering or a mask when in a public place where they can’t maintain a six-foot social distance. Face-coverings will be required in public indoor spaces, such as stores. This new requirement applies to all individuals over the age of two who are able to medically tolerate a face-covering or a mask.

8 years old and older shall wear face coverings inside indoor places open to the public (except private offices, private workspaces or meetings in which six feet of distancing can be achieved), in outdoor public spaces that cannot meet this social distancing requirement and inside public transportation. Exceptions: Food consumption, faculty and staff with social distancing, people practicing exercises and people with medical conditions that prevent them from wearing facial protection.
The governor said counties do not have the right to enforce anyone to wear masks

The first mask order identifies public settings as: indoor spaces that are accessible to the public such as grocery stores, retail stores, pharmacies and health care facilities; outdoor spaces such as playgrounds, busy parking lots, and other areas such as lines for take-out service where the public typically gathers in a smaller area; and public transportation such as a taxi, Uber, Lyft, ride-sharing or similar service; ferry, bus, or train; and any semi-enclosed transit stop or waiting area.The policy has been strengthened on 05/29/2020, which requires wearing masks in large gatherings; It has been strengthened again on 07/08/2020, which applies for coastal cities in Maine https://www.newscentermaine.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/mills-signs-executive-order-mandating-mask-enforcement-extends-state-of-emergency-through-august-6/97-288108be-187f-44a0-9cd8-98185ac56fedThe

A state-wide mask mandate first went into effect on April 18, though it was only targeted at business employees and their customers: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-24.pdf. It was later expanded to all persons in public spaces; this went into effect on May 8: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-30.pdf. The state-wide mask mandate for all persons was then extended twice: once until July 4, and again until August 2. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-41.pdf https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-52.pdf

A state-wide emergency requirement regarding face coverings took effect on August 3 in accordance with CDC and DHEC guidelines. However, it is a limited mask requirement across the state which only applied to part of the places and public settings, mostly indoor public places including all restaurants, entertainment venues, and government buildings.
No state-wide mask mandate in place as of September 8, 2020. Masks have never been required, but South Dakotans are encouraged to continue to consider CDC guidance and use.
